text: Sure. But no one has to go that far for my argument to stand. It can be less or more important depending on the group or the situation. The "Enemy Within" is often a more potent concept than the unwanted incomer.

text: Carl, within my sentient lifetime "most people" said no such thing about men and women. It may be "widely considered" unacceptable now, but there was a hell of a fight getting there.
author: DAaronovitch

text: And not just that. The problems of "lost male dignity at work" or the "loss of community" to economic and social change (including family change) are also bigger in actual impact than immigration. Again, I'm not talking about voters' perceptions.
author: DAaronovitch

text: We were. But for many at the time women's lib was a joke to do with bra-burning and the wider implications took far longer to manifest themselves.
author: DAaronovitch

text: And incidentally, since when was that a historic rule? You think that, for example, 50s everyday racism made a total distinction between black Britons and black immigrants?
author: DAaronovitch

text: Maybe, but my point is that these dislocations are far, far bigger.
author: DAaronovitch

text: It's not that glacial. Some of the changes in gender relations have been incredibly quick. Look at women and higher education for example. Or employment. To your credit D, you're one of very few to have discussed this at all.
author: DAaronovitch

text: I am not talking either about what "voters" do or don't perceive, according to poll questions, but about what causes actual social disruption and change.
author: DAaronovitch

text: It's not an answer to that point to talk about obligations to fellow members of the imagined community.
author: DAaronovitch

text: No. I am not conflating. It is probably my fault but you and Rob are both missing my point. If the problem is, say, social dislocation and a sense of rapid change, then gender equality has had far more impact than migration. Yet it is almost never raised in this context.
author: DAaronovitch

text: I don't know why but you're now combining an unnecessary piety with a restatement of the obvious. I think I'll leave it there.
author: DAaronovitch

text: I said I noted it, not that I was making it a focus of my argument. And it wasn't the daftness that mattered. it was the association. And thus, completely unwittingly, you have just done to me what you say should not be done.
author: DAaronovitch

text: My point was trying to go wider than today's discussion about migration. If the "problem" is one of adjustment to changing social mores (as it is often posed) why is women's equality nearly always left out?
author: DAaronovitch

text: I'm not sure we're discussing the same thing, exactly. Though I did note the recent BBC vox pop from Mansfield with a man saying that now we were out of the EU we wouldn't have to run a foreign aid budget.

text: Don't stop there, Eric. Which non-prejudices do you think have been wrongly and widely ascribed to prejudice?
author: DAaronovitch

text: At the moment (it seems to me) the dominant intellectual proposition is that cosmopolitan "liberalism", by its impositions, has provoked a backlash from more authentic members of the community. But the thing that has changed most (gender equality) is least cited by proposers.
author: DAaronovitch

text: There is another complementary explanation, which is that people genuinely don't want to face up to their own prejudices, Eric.
author: DAaronovitch

text: Well indeed. It's interesting to me what gets excluded when it comes to the idea of "liberal" values being imposed on an unconsulted population. After all the biggest social change of all has been in the position of women in society.
author: DAaronovitch
